Module kivakit.configuration
Package com.telenav.kivakit.configuration

Class ConfigurationSet

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.telenav.kivakit.kernel.messaging.broadcasters.Multicaster
      • com.telenav.kivakit.kernel.messaging.repeaters.BaseRepeater
        • com.telenav.kivakit.configuration.ConfigurationSet
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Receiver<Transmittable>, Transmitter<Transmittable>, Named, NamedObject, PackagePathed, Broadcaster, Listener, Repeater, Transceiver, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Object>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConfigurationFolder, ConfigurationPackage, Deployment
    public class ConfigurationSet
extends BaseRepeater
implements Named, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Object>
    A mutable set of (untyped) configuration Objects that can be loaded from a package or folder. Configuration objects can be queried by class, and with an optional instance identifier in cases where more than one configuration object of a given class is in use.

    The Global Configuration Set

    Configuration information is generally loaded into the global configuration set, which allows configuration objects to be easily queried from client code anywhere. Configuration sets can be added to the global set with install(). This method is used in Deployment to install the configuration objects for a server deployment in the global set. See Deployment for a detailed example of how this works.

    This class is the base class for Deployment, which holds configuration objects relevant to a particular server deployment, as well as ConfigurationFolder and ConfigurationPackage, which load configuration information from folders and packages, respectively. Configurations objects are loaded automatically when they are requested and each .properties resource describes just one configuration object. This means that a configuration folder or package will often have more than one .properties resource in it.

    Locating Configurations with Lookup

    For convenience, each configuration object is added to the global lookup. This allows clients to easily look up configuration objects and not depend on where they came from. For example: 

         var serverSettings = Lookup.global().locate(ServerSettings.class)

    Properties File Format

    Properties files are of this general form:

    Server1.properties

     class=com.telenav.navigation.my.application.Server$Configuration
 configuration-instance=SERVER1
 port=aws.amazon.com:7001

    Here, the "class" key designates a class to instantiate (note that the nested class has to be indicated with '$' rather than '.' here). The object that is created from this class is populated with the property values by using ObjectPopulator, which automatically converts each property value into an object using the converter framework. To do this, properties in the configuration object are tagged with KivaKitPropertyConverter indicating which converter the ObjectPopulator should use to convert a string value in the properties file to the corresponding object. For example, in this case the property converter for the configuration class above is Port.Converter and the port property is converted to a Port object:

    Server.Configuration Class

     public class Configuration
 {
     private Port port;

    @KivaKitPropertyConverter(Port.Converter.class)
     public void port(final Port port)
     {
         this.port = port;
     }

    [...]
 }

    The key "configuration-instance" designates which instance of the configuration the properties file is configuring, in the event that more than one object of the same type is being configured.

    Locating Configuration Objects at Runtime

    Once a configuration set (usually the global configuration set, which can be retrieved with global()) has been loaded with configuration information, that information can be queried with:

    • has(Class) - Determines if a configuration object of the given type exists
    • has(Class, InstanceIdentifier) - Determines if the specified instance of given configuration object type exists
    • get(Class) - Gets the configuration object of the given type
    • get(Class, InstanceIdentifier) - Gets the specified instance of the configuration object with the given type
    • get(Class, Enum) - Gets the specified instance of the configuration object with the given type
    • require(Class) - Gets the specified configuration object or fails with Ensure.fail()
    • require(Class, InstanceIdentifier) - Gets the specified configuration object instance or fails with Ensure.fail()
    • require(Class, Enum) - Gets the specified configuration object instance or fails with Ensure.fail()

    Loading Configurations as DeploymentSets

    The details below are present for flexibility and will not be necessary most of the time. To understand how to load and use collections of configuration objects called deployments in an Application, see Deployment.

    Adding and Loading Configuration Objects

    • addPackage(Class, String) - Adds the package of .properties files at the given path relative to the given class
    • addFolder(Folder) - Adds the folder of .properties files
    • addDeployment(Deployment) - Merges a deployment into this configuration set
    • install() - Installs the contents of this ConfigurationSet into the global configuration set

    In most cases, it will not be necessary to manually add configuration objects to a set. They can be automatically loaded and added by using the Deployment and DeploymentSet classes and occasionally with ConfigurationPackage and ConfigurationFolder. When it is necessary, configuration objects can be added with:

    • add(Object) - Adds the configuration object to this set
    • add(Object, InstanceIdentifier) - Adds the configuration object of the specified instance to this set
    • add(Object, Enum) - Adds the configuration object of the specified instance to this set
    • addAll(Collection) - Adds the collection of configuration objects to this set
    • addSet(ConfigurationSet) - Adds the objects in the given configuration set to this set

    Configuration objects are loaded transparently by using the Deployment, ConfigurationFolder and ConfigurationPackage subclasses of this class. For example: 

     var development = new ConfigurationFolder(new Folder("development"));
 development.forEach(System.out::println);
    Author:
    jonathanl (shibo)
    See Also:
    Deployment, ConfigurationFolder, ConfigurationPackage
